137936: Armillary Sphere.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
137936: Armillary Sphere.text_parsed: Four mana is kind of steep for what this card does, but I wonder if Esper can possibly break this card through recursion. My instincts say no. Deck thinning is a great tactic when it can be done at 0 mana cost (through the various Baubles), but it rarely is worth much more than that. Compare this to Knight of the Reliquary, for example, as a means to thin your deck and you'll see that the Armillary Sphere is vastly inferior. Armillary Sphere is a decent mana-fixer, and might be useful in multi-colored decks that don't use green. But if I had to choose between Armillary Sphere and one of the shard Obelisks (i.e. Obelisk of Grixis), I think I'd go with the Obelisk.
137936: Armillary Sphere.text_posted: Four mana is kind of steep for what this card does, but I wonder if Esper can possibly break this card through recursion.  My instincts say no. Armillary Sphere is a decent mana-fixer, and might be useful in multi-colored decks that don't use green. But if I had to choose between Armillary Sphere and one of the shard Obelisks (i.e. [autocard]Obelisk of Grixis[/autocard]), I think I'd go with the Obelisk.

137936: Armillary Sphere.author: Atrues
137936: Armillary Sphere.text_parsed:
2 mana then 2 mana is not EXACLTY the same as 4 mana... but lets see what this card does...

first, it's an artifact... esper goodness.
2 and blow it up, search your deck for 2 basic lands and add them to your hands. This is mana fixing AND filtering. After you filter your deck your less likely to draw land when you dont need it, so it does give you a card advantage, and becuase you just added 2 lands to your hand, you won't miss a drop for a couple turns...
Then its an artifact in your grave, there are a few cards in esper that like this..

All in all.. meh. Its actually a Little better than the obelisks in the long run, as it does filter and you won't miss drops, but esper will get the most use out of it (they can reduce it's cost by 1, this also applies to the obelisk, but the sphere STILL beats it thanks to the filter).
It's priced EXACTLY right, meaning its not a cool as it could be..

It'll get higher marks in 5 color builds but even in 3 color it's not bad.

137936: Armillary Sphere.author: rage4lifebj
137936: Armillary Sphere.text_parsed:
This card is very underrated. 2 mana and then 2 mana is not at all equal to 4 mana (probably closer to 3).
The Sphere is designed for longer games: hitting your land drops each turn is important for control decks, but also for any deck with expensive bombs. And deck thinning is more powerful the longer the game lasts.

If you're not in green (for better mana building) and don't have awesome card drawing, a couple of these can go a long way!

138571: Nacatl Hunt-Pride.author: Oleander
138571: Nacatl Hunt-Pride.text_parsed: Cost aside, this card is pretty amazing. I don't think most people realize that you can use it's abilities when you attack with it, as the vigilance allows you to use the tap abilities when you declare attackers, meaning that you can attack with these kitties and force an opponent to send a creature to the frontline. Unless your opponent is packing some major heat or tricky stat alterations, these cats can clear through most anything that stands in their way.

142301: Rupture Spire.author: Bauble
142301: Rupture Spire.text_parsed:
I play a control/esper deck, so Ancient Ziggurat just doesn't work for me. It leaves me with just that one mana less to play a certain spell (I.e Cancel or Silence) that could decide the game from the beginning. This is slower, but much more versatile. For obvious reasons, using this on turn 2 or late-game makes the most sense to me. Of course, that 1 mana cost is a pain in the butt, and the fact that this card comes into play tapped is irritating as well. Yeah, it definitely has its drawbacks, for example, having no lands but 1 or 2 of this in your opening hand demands a mulligan, or in mid-game when you're letting your spells fly loose, you draw this and can't play it because it costs 1 mana to play; 1 mana that you just can't come through without.

But all in all, for non-aggro decks, I'd give this card a mighty fine 4/5.

142301: Rupture Spire.author: Donovan_Fabian
142301: Rupture Spire.text_parsed: I would rather play with pillar of the paruns, ancient ziggurat, or reflecting pool.. however it being a common means its cheap to buy and anytime after turn 1 that you can spare a mana the spire gives you any colored mana land for the rest of the game.  I'm conflicted as to whether I feel this is better, or worse, than a simple trace of abundance.  Technically, since it comes into play tapped, and you have to pay a mana to keep it, it costs the equivalent of 2 mana.  A trace of abundance for the same 2 mana, can be placed on a land that hasn't yet been tapped, netting you an immediate 1 mana gain, that rupture spire simply can't do.

Not bad, but a definite slow-down of your curve if you're running 4 of them. I love the flexibility of mana, but if it runs in a deck with other lands which enter tapped, you're going to experience some frustrating early turns.

Still though, an obviously better-than average card.

3.5/5

My viewpoint of this card has changed drastically since i first saw this card. Originally i saw it as a waste of an uncommon. Spellbook wasnt even a popular card in standard, so why would a Spellbook land be any better?

Of course once i saw its potential in decks like Turbo Fog and Cruel Control, i quickly changed my opinion. Now it's still decent at best, but at least it has found a home in some very popular archetypes.

150826: Asha's Favor.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
150826: Asha's Favor.text_parsed: Play it with Sigil of the Empty Throne, and it won't seem like card disadvantage. Auras are getting better and better, but in today's spot-removal rich metagame, they're also pretty risky. 150826: Asha's Favor.author: majinara

I don't like this card.
If I have no creatures: useless.
If I have small creatures: useless.
If I have large creatures that already got some of the abilities: useless.
If my opponent has any type of removal of any sorts: card disadvantage.
Does it make my creatures bigger? No. Kill opponents faster? Nope. Harder to kill? Nope.

The only thing this does is making a large creatures slightly better. If I have a large creatures in play the thing I want to do most is protect it or give it trample. This does neither. I'd never play this thing.

150847: Voices from the Void.author: NoobOfLore
150847: Voices from the Void.text_parsed:
@Champion_Kitsune: "Conflux sucked pretty bad."

For people who don't like domain, and people who like their games to last less than 5 turns.
Conflux was an awesome set for multicolor, which, while not for everybody, is generally more fun for the Johnnies, Timmies, and Melvins among us.

This card is 5 discard for 5. Few cards give you such a good deal, and any deck that's running Domain almost certainly has some sort of mana ramp, guys. Let's not pretend like it's impossible for this to hit before turn 5.
Turn 4 plays of this card should be common, and turn 3 wouldn't be too hard to set up.

It's Mind Sludge for domain, don't hate it.

The Mystics are particularly synergistic with Bant's exalted ability (which doesn't target) and useful against the spot removal which is so prevalent in today's meta.  The Mystics have a lot of competition for roster slots in competitive Bant decks, however, and probably won't see much constructed play.

153946: Aerie Mystics.author: heenaheena
153946: Aerie Mystics.text_parsed:
I don't think this card is really all that great. I'd rather pay less to give one or two of my creatures shroud with something like sylvan safekeeper or vines of vastwood because my opponent will most likely only be targeting one or two creatures per turn.

@ Thisprofilemocksyou,
I don't think you understand what shroud does. A creature with shroud will be destroyed by effects that "destroy all creatures" because those effects don't target specific creatures. So wrath of god, day of judgment, damnation and nevinyrral's disk will still destroy your creatures even if you've given them shroud. MtG rules are conveniently literal so unless a card specifically says "target" in reference to the permanent(s) it intends to effect, shroud is meaningless.

154081: Inkwell Leviathan.author: Zaneshift
154081: Inkwell Leviathan.text_parsed: I imprint this on Summoner's Eggs then Pongify the egg. A 7/11 with trample and shroud is just plain evil, even without a quick-play combo. Eleven toughness! That's just insane! Islandwalk might not be the best unblockable sort of ability, but it's hardly that much of a problem since you're not going to get him killed unless your opponent has 11 damage lined up for their attackers (which is nice if you lure them into blocking then bounce/tap enough creatures to keep the leviathan alive). I've yet to see a game that I can't win after playing Inkwell Leviathan. He simply isn't going down when you're running control (and your opponent wastes a massive amount of resources in the process). He's not the most damaging giant creature, but he doesn't need to be.

154081: Inkwell Leviathan.author: yyukichigai
154081: Inkwell Leviathan.text_parsed:
I love how the reduced cost on this guy for being an artifact is massively, massively offset by the fact that you can't target him. What's more, why would you need to target him? Well I suppose if you're not the one controlling him and you're about to get a faceful of waterey death....

Awesome by himself, yet combos well with quite a few cards. Even if you can't give him an Island to work with, you have Trample to tear through nearly anything.

Also, the art reminds me of a specific Calvin and Hobbes strip with Calvin imagining a rather unfortunate Farmer Brown.

154081: Inkwell Leviathan.author: Mode
154081: Inkwell Leviathan.text_parsed:
Something like shroud is just one of the most important things for your finishers if they aren't the really big ones that are likely to kill your opponents in about two hits, especially if they're also artifacts.
You don't get anything from casting an expensive creature if your opponent's removal spell still works just as fine on those and only costs something between one or three mana.

@TheLionsMane: This is the thought process of every guy in a lighthouse from Magic :D
Check out the other Leviathan cards' artworks, they all have them in some way.

154081: Inkwell Leviathan.author: Salient

This, Stormtide, Kederekt, wow. Leviathans rock nowadays. Everyone who was alive for the Ice Age expansion reads over this card twenty times looking for the crippling Krakenesque drawback. Delightfully weird that it's an artifact creature. Who built it?

154081: Inkwell Leviathan.author: Gamalgoth

you will basically win at this point, just make sure to have counter spells handy for those pesky board wipes, you are pretty safe from volcanic fallout

158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.author: CeremonialBathory
158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.text_parsed: @rinoh20 - I, personally, am getting tired of every ability finding its way in to white. In the recent sets, white has had access to counter spells (albeit not as strong as blue - it's there), tons of control (like Ethersworn Canonist, Silence etc,), the best removal that was available in standard (Oblivion Ring, Path to Exile, Journey to Nowhere) and this wouldn't be a problem if they weren't printed en masse. White doesn't deserve trample this easily. Bant Battlemage giving trample is fine because it requires a color that thematically has it. Conditional trample could even be acceptable. Why is it alright for white to get these off color pie abilities but people shit bricks when red gets back Lightning Bolt, or Blue gets a competent beater (Sphinx of Jwar Isle)? The only reason white hasn't been completely insane in the newest set is because it's Mirroden and that level of insanity is reserved for artifacts. I'd be fine with power creep if it didn't seem so damn one sided in every other set.

158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.author: OneFishTwoFish
158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.text_parsed:
@Tommy9898 - "Ugh, I'm so sick of everyone point out how good Doubling Season "combos" with every single token maker ever. THINK HARDER!!!!!!!"

Parallel Lives! Am I thinking hard enough yet?
No? How about Paradox Haze?
What? Still too easy? Vesuvan Doppelganger! Can I go home yet?
No? No?!
...
Fine then. The gauntlet has been thrown down.
Thoughtlace, Painter's Servant, or Shifting Sky for greater self-sufficiency.
Diplomatic Immunity for endurance.
Dreams of the Dead for back-up. (Note: The copies will not have the cumulative upkeep.)
Rhys the Redeemed for overkill.

Further examination of Paradox Haze reveals that you can Mirrorweave all your white weenies into Mirror-Sigil Sergeants before your second upkeep.
Further examination of Vesuvan Doppelganger reveals that not only will it become a self-sufficient Mirror-Sigil Sergeant, but you can also stack its copy-target-creature upkeep trigger above its duplicate-self upkeep trigger, allowing you to make your shiny new Vesuvan Doppelganger token a copy of any creature right from the get-go. Cool, but not necessarily all that useful when your alternative is MOAR RHINOS!

158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.author: Aquillion
158598: Mirror-Sigil Sergeant.text_parsed:
The problem with all the combos with him is that it's just too slow. He costs six mana to begin with; then, no matter what you do, you have to wait one turn until your next upkeep, and another turn before any of the copies can actually attack (since they enter with summoning sickness themselves.) Even then, all but the most extreme (and card-intensive and therefore impractical) combos aren't going to produce enough copies to kill your opponent for another turn or two. And, of course, one timely piece of removal can stop the whole thing before it starts.

Everyone says Doubling Season or Paradox Haze, but the thing is, you first have to ask "should I use this card?" And truthfully, here are much better and much faster things to combo with Doubling Season or Paradox Haze than this.

159610: Bloodhall Ooze.author: DoctorKenneth
159610: Bloodhall Ooze.text_parsed:
Well, the mentality behind this, I would assume, goes as follows:
Any creature that restricts it's own potential so as to be situational deserves a boost in power. Sure, Wolf-Skull Shaman potentially spills 2/2 tokens on the board, but only if you're playing an elf deck. If not, he's a slightly better Grizzly Bear. It's a good card, but only if a hoop is jumped through. A card like Cancel is good due to it's placement in a number of blue decks, it's non-adherence to a certain strategy, and it's lack of hoops to jump through. If you pay 1UU, you're getting a Cancel, not a potentially stronger or weaker Cancel.

Now here's how that logic is flawed. Players are going to jump around the hoops in unexpected ways. They can ignore the hoops and break them in half. And chances are, if one takes the time to build a deck around the hoops (decks that have lots of support already- elf decks for Wolf-Skull Shaman, or Jund decks for the ooze), these cards can get out of control. When the deck is actually made, there is no downside. You're playing around it. And sometimes the benifits are so strong they dominate the game. It's like being rewarded for what you were going to do anyway.

Overpowered? Certainly not. But it gets frustratingly annoying having to race faster and faster decks, who seem to have gained speed by giving up something they didn't care about anyway.

But...um....it's good to see oozes featured on more cards.

159610: Bloodhall Ooze.author: DacenOctavio
159610: Bloodhall Ooze.text_parsed:
@ ChuckMickey:

Basic Lands are defined as colorless permanents with the ability "tap: add one mana of the given color to your mana pool."

Nonbasic lands are colorless permanents that may or may not have such an ability, may may tap for more than one color of mana, or may simply be fetch lands.

The given color is indicated in the current printings of land cards by the large mana symbol on the lower section of the card, but since the permanent itself has no mana cost, it has no color. For this reason, you could use a non-basic land like Valakut, the Molten Pinnacle to synergize with a mono-red deck and maneuver around cards that have Protection from Red, such as Kor Firewalker. Which would be essentially casting a colorless Lightning Bolt at near-instant speed.

@ DoctorKenneth:

You mean like putting Dragon Appeasement in an eldrazi spawn deck with Sarkhan the Mad, Grave Pact, Where Ancients Tread, and cheap, fast hitting eldrazi? At that point, Dragon Appeasement is no longer a bad Necropotence. Together with all the enchantments it makes your spawns and creatures you sac to Sarkhan read "Sacrifice this creature: Draw two cards. Each other player sacrifices a creature. If you control Rockslide Elemental, rape someone's face. If a spawn was sacrificed this way, add {1} to your mana pool. Otherwise, Where Ancients Tread deals 5 damage to target creature or player."

@ Tezz:

Run in conjunction with Scute Mob. It will put people off.

Basic Lands are defined as colorless permanents with the ability "tap: add one mana of the given color to your mana pool."

Nonbasic lands are colorless permanents that may or may not have such an ability, may may tap for more than one color of mana, or may simply be fetch lands.

The given color is indicated in the current printings of land cards by the large mana symbol on the lower section of the card, but since the permanent itself has no mana cost, it has no color. 159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.author: Donovan_Fabian
159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.text_parsed:
At 4 mana and being one of the only life linkers in the game let alone with haste and not having a lame 1 toughness like giant solifuge, ball lightning, and lightning elemental, got to love this creature. Maybe not the most powerful by a long shot, but it can certainly make its way into a competitive deck. It's 3 toughness is to balance out that your getting a 5 power haste lifelinker for 4 mana, which is the same on rakeclaw gargantuan and it's first strike ability.

After testing this guy out he's really amazing, for starters he's only takes 4 mana and only one of that has to be green. He gets his boosts from anything that has white or red and stays on the field, including equipment cards, artifacts, creatures, or planeswalkers. Can use thoctars, trace of abundance, ajani vengeant and so on to get his abilities working. Sneaking in a hasting 5 power lifelinker is a great way to start a turn 3 or 4. It's still a 5/3 even with nothing else in play. If you think about it like it was a sorcery, and that sorcery read for 4 mana deal 5 damage to opponent or opponents creature and gain 5 life, it puts it in a different perspective. Just insane with stuff like giant growth for lots of life gain (can also use wall of reverence) or behemoth sledge. It's not so much a game ending card, as much as a really solid creature who can bring the beats.

159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.author: JaxsonBateman
159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.text_parsed:
It's not a bad creature by any means. Unfortunately, it just gets overshadowed by everything else. Even in standard - the only format he'd really have a chance in - you're looking at at least Vengevines in the 4 mana spot. You'd definitely be going at least GR or GW if you wanted to play him - in GW alone you'd also be running Fauna Shaman, Knight of the Reliquary, Dauntless Escort, Noble Hierarch, and if you really wanted another creature at 4+ mana you'd probably put in either Ranger of Eos to fuel Vengevine or Thornling. In GR you'd be running Birds, Cunning Sparkmage, Bloodbraid Elf, and again, Thornling would take precedence.

It's a similar case as Serra Angel - by no means a bad card, but it won't ever see constructed play again due to the existence of Baneslayer Angel.

159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.author: sweetgab
159612: Cliffrunner Behemoth.text_parsed:
In today's Standard, this would have been strong. Back then Lightning Bolt existed, and if you want to play mid-sized creatures, they need to either have numbers as good as Baneslayer Angel, or gives you cards like Bloodbraid Elf, or both like Wurmcoil Engine.

As I mentioned elsewhere, I believe Lightning Bolt was the card that started all the power creep since it saw print in M10. Because not even a four mana 5/3 haste lifelink could see a little play in its presence, so you'd need to make stronger creatures, and then stronger answers to those creatures. It was a vicious cycle. With the removal of Lightning Bolt from Standard, things are much better now.

159629: Dreadwing.text_parsed:
You folks seem to be overrating him. He's a 1/1 for 1. Ignoring his ability for a second, lets look at the 1 drop creatures that just came out with Zendikar:

Steppe Lynx - easily capable of being a 4/5 on turn 2 without even using mana.
Cosi's Trickster - the worst of the 5 colours, but still able to be boosted without mana (and either shuts down fetchlands or gets rewarded for the opponent using them)
Vampire Lacerator/Guul Draz Vampire - the first is a 2/2 for 1, meaning on its strength alone it will outdo its drawback. Guul Draz starts off weak, but gets very strong with good evasion mid game.
Goblin Guide - 2/2 with haste. Its drawback isn't even that bad - if your opponent is playing second and you give them a land, unless they can also use a 1 drop they have to discard. If you don't give them land on turns, you see what they're topdecking.
Scythe Tiger - 3/2 with shroud. Sacrificing a land is a massive disadvantage, but in limited shroud can make it a very nasty proposition.
Scute Mob - early game, pretty ordinary. Mid to late game? Destroy creature spell please.

A 1/1 for 1 isn't appealing, and given that until late in the game the activated ability is going to tie down a lot of your mana (not to mention that even after using it it's still destroyable by 1 single damage) it doesn't seem worthwhile at all.

174792: Scepter of Dominance.author: Kiro
174792: Scepter of Dominance.text_parsed:
Let's have a look at Tumble Magnet, which is heavily played, then let's take a look at the scepter again. Both have their strengths and weaknesses. Tumble Magnet only has three charge counters and needs support (proliferate, or artifact bounce) to keep going beyond three activations. But it also doesn't require one mana to activate so it's even a turn faster. And obviously it can be played outside of white. And it doesn't fizzle against pro-white of course.

But the scepter is very strong all by itself. You don't need to play any support cards for this to be worth your while. Tumble Magnet is just ... meh without any cards that grant charge counters or allow you to bounce the magnet so you can replay it with three fresh counters. Also the scepter can tap any kind of permanent, including lands. It also works great in tandem with Voltaic Key and other untappers. Tumble Magnet depletes ultra fast, while Scepter of Dominance never depletes.

The Scepter shines with stuff like Howling Mine. Also it greatly appreciates turn two acceleration. Turn two Mind Stone into turn three Scepter + activation is really nice. From then on it will tap down the most valuable permanent every turn. It also forces your opponent to over-commit. So he plays another creature or two two be able to attack past your Scepter and whoops, there's the Day of Judgment.

This is a strong card in the right deck. And I don't mean "If this and that and when you combo it with some obscure card and the stars align, then it's good."-good. This is not one of those cases. It's just a really good card that also has very good synergy with the cards that come in it's color. (Like Day of Judgment) It's a house in any white control deck.

4.5/5.

174792: Scepter of Dominance.author: Henrietta
174792: Scepter of Dominance.text_parsed:
I have to disagree with your assessment of the Scepter, it's not an awful card but Tumble Magnet is quite a bit better than it in general, and even in a mono-white control deck with no support cards it is still slightly better. The three activations can be relevant but is often less relevant than you'd think, compared to the mana cost to activate. Tumble Magnets are a lot more than 'meh' with just 3 activations, as that gives you ample time to find an answer to the threat you're trying to stop, or just kill them outright. The scepter is better for shenanigans like Howling Mine, I admit, but, you know, you jump on Tumble Magnet for being best with support, so it's a bit hypocritical.

Anyways, not a bad card, but it's worse than Tumble Magnet in general and is only really better in certain niche roles. On a competitive 1v1 rating scale, I'd give the Tumble Magnet a 2.5/5 or 3.0/5 and this Scepter a 2.0/5.

When you just can't get that card you need, or you're holding four lands and nothing useful in your hand, you always have the option of whipping these suckers back out of the graveyard for some easy damage or pressure. The second use of these mean elementals is why I run 4 in my red aggro decks almost every time. Certainly there are red aggro decks where this won't be an ideal card, but for most it's too good for the cost to pass up.

174953: Skyward Eye Prophets.author: RAV0004
174953: Skyward Eye Prophets.text_parsed:
Gold cards are ones that each give a powerful effect to a card (whereas hybrid cards each utilize an effect both colors have equal access to).

White's giving it vigilance.
Blue is giving it draw.
Green is giving it Land accel.

It's interesting to note that this card could have costed 2UWG and been far more beloved. It's interesting to note that this card could have costed 1UWG and never even touched a tournament, standard or otherwise, just like it does now.

It's also humorous that the card would have been "far too good" if it cost 4 and was still a 3/3, and would have broken apart drafts and limited. It would have had to been knocked down to a 2/2 or worse, like a 1/3 or a 1/1.

175026: Lapse of Certainty.author: masail19
175026: Lapse of Certainty.text_parsed: Counterspells have a place in every colour, but blue happens to be king of "no", rather than the only colour allowed to have it. Blue gets a lot of variation in countermagic, while other colours seem to carry themes. White counterspells usually involve control or protection. Red or green counterspells are typically hosers against countermagic or blue. Black doesn't usually get countermagic, but when it does get it, it tends to punish your opponents.

The reason they increased the cost over Memory Lapse is because this is in white and hence must be over budgeted compared to a blue spell.

Red already got a counter-esque spell in the form of Guttural Response.

In my opinion this card is rated far too low. For white to have access to a Counterspell alone makes this ideal in many situations and decks. Scenarios where you can stall out major plays on their part (ie: Counter Baneslayer Angel if you don't have removal handy) even for a turn can be game changing.

175026: Lapse of Certainty.author: james2c19v
175026: Lapse of Certainty.text_parsed:
I think that this or something like it should be reprinted. I like the idea of the various mana colors bleeding into each other. Blue gets the most powerful and straight-up counters, but black and white should get something similar. If black had to pay life, discard cards, and/or sacrifice creatures to counter, I think that'd still be flavorful. For white then to get a counter-to-the-library also seems appropriate (it fits with stuff like Oust).

Also, and more importantly, you need stuff like this to play mono-white. Otherwise you have to splash black or something just to get rid of stuff like Ward Sliver. This isn't even a complete answer, but at least it can stall it from coming out and wrecking your game.

175026: Lapse of Certainty.author: SAUS3
175026: Lapse of Certainty.text_parsed:
At 3 mana, it is a little tough to cast, but that doesn't stop it from being a powerful counterspell. Being off-colour helps it in multiple ways - you can use it in a deck that would otherwise have no counterspells, and you can also throw off your opponent.

I use it as part of my sunforger arsenal in my Tajic deck. It kicks butt because if I'm swinging with my sunforger (6/2 indestructible Tajic, 11/7 if I have battalion), there is no room for you to lose a turn due to a counterspell.

It also sets up a soft lock combined with sunforger and mistveil plains. I can counter a spell every turn, and it puts it on top of your deck, limiting what you draw. It basically forces you to sit there until you draw a way out (usually 2 removal spells or a removal spell and a counterspell). That usually takes too long. Each time you 'force' something through by casting multiple spells, you lose your next draw as well (to one of those cards).

Land's Edge
Seismic Assault
Stormbind
Lightning Storm

175035: Ethersworn Adjudicator.author: DarthParallax
175035: Ethersworn Adjudicator.text_parsed:
Funny- even though Black is normally bad at killing enchantments- worse than anyone else except Red-

It just seems to me like specifically White + Black ought to be better at it than any other color pair- including even White + Green. Does that make sense?
Sort of a 'Light Side + Dark Side = Destroy the Force' kind of logic?

Cuz really, White and Green generally don't like the word 'destroy' at all. Black loves Destroy though, so it more quickly adapts to killing stuff if you give it another color to work with than White or Green would.
Although recently, it seems they have decided to push 'Fangorn Green' -see cards like Bramblecrush

"The Forest will wake up...and find that it is strong"

175401: Worldheart Phoenix.author: tngms
175401: Worldheart Phoenix.text_parsed: This card is far from overpowered and it can't fit into typical red decks, but I still like it. For a somewhat crappy creature (2/2 or 4/4 flier) it's hard to get rid of for good (since it returns itself from the graveyard directly to play). As I said before, it's not overpowered since it costs 4 to play the first time (when its a measly 2/2) and the colorful 5 is a complicated investment for just a 4/4 flier. But it does have a cool effect that can be relevant in slow casual games. It's a decent include budget multicolor decks, as something with a lot of green/red can manage to get at least one of the other colors.

175401: Worldheart Phoenix.author: Donovan_Fabian
175401: Worldheart Phoenix.text_parsed: I like it for the most part, but I would still gripe about the part that bothers me most, the mana cost paired with the power.  What I want to see on a phoenix should read, 3/3 for 5 mana, if it dies you may pay 3 and 1 r to bring back the phoenix into play with 2 counters as a 5/5 flying with haste and first strike.  That would be cool because it doesn't have those abilities unless it dies and is brought back in first place, but if it isn't exiled or something it can pay out big.  Either way, having a creature that can potentially be brought back from the graveyard over and over can be really good, especially when paired with gorgon flail, for a 5/5 flying death touch that you don't care if it dies or not.  Electropotence also a pricey, but effective combination, 8 mana puts the phoenix back into play and does 4 burn damage to target of your choice.

175401: Worldheart Phoenix.author: Azazyel
175401: Worldheart Phoenix.text_parsed:
Pulled the idea from an old Building on a Budget article from 2009 and tried to make a control deck using this as a win-con. The idea is that this think escapes board wipes, and all targeted removal save for Path/Swords, so even if it gets killed or countered you can recur it and win.

Problem - the ability only functions at sorcery speed. Nothing kills the buzz of paying at the end of an opponents turn only to realize that since the Phoenix is cast, it can only be played at any time you could cast a creature.

This puts a damper on the control strategy of the deck, since in order to recur the Phoenix you're forced to shut off mana you could've used for card draw instants and counterspells.

I guess if you could find a way to give it flash...

175401: Worldheart Phoenix.author: GrimjawxRULES
175401: Worldheart Phoenix.text_parsed:
I remember this being tournament playable at some point. 5 color control ran these as their finishers because they were nearly impossible to deal with, and it's easy to see why. It's easily cast the first time around (only one red mana in its cost), and after that, you're recurring a 4/4 flyer that takes 20 % of your opponent's life every turn unless they waste another removal spell on it.
Two things are especially worth noting with this card: Firstly, you cast it, meaning it can be countered by an opponent, and secondly, it's one of the few (strong) creatures that you can repeatedly return from your graveyard to play. Each time your opponent uses a Doomblade or Terror to get rid of it, you're gaining card advantage.

177927: Grixis Illusionist.author: SIlverSkyz
177927: Grixis Illusionist.text_parsed:
@ bijart_dauth

Sadly that doesn't work. This ability is "until end of turn" not "the beginning of the next end step" so activating it end the end step does nothing, it still changes back at the end of the turn.
Same idea as Giant Growth really. If Giant growth was cast during combat to save a creature, and it was phrased as "until the beginning of the next end step" the creature would still die. So it actually happens during the cleanup phase when you discard down to your hand-size, remove all damage from creatures, and "until end of turn" and "this turn" affects end.

-Army combo-

Coat of Arms+Conqueror's Pledge (not kicked)+Martial Coup(X mana paid=5)=

-10 soldiers in total (Martial Coup+Conqueror's Pledge)
-Destroy all opposing creatures (Martial Coup)
-Every single one of the 10 soldiers is +11/+11 (Coat of Arms), thus, total combat damage= 110 combat damage damage
-Mana cost: 12 (Martial Coup+Conqueror's Pledge)
-Impractical combo

-Add Dauntless Escort in case the other player uses a AoE destruction spell
-Add Sigil Captain or Armament Master to add more salt to the other player's wounds :P (in fact you can use these two cards in place of Coat of Arms but the total combat damage will be 40)

178560: Martial Coup.author: SliverApocalypse
178560: Martial Coup.text_parsed:
If you were going to Bloom Tender + Crab Umbra for infinite mana, you might as well just run a direct damage red spell such as Brightflame with Autumn's Veil covering and ignore the entire idea of Martial Coup all together, seeing as you need to run a 4 to 5 color deck just to have the infinite mana combo work (Read Bloom Tender's rules; You only get a maxium of (B)(U)(G)(R)(W) from tapping it). When you have infinite mana you ramp into direct damage or life gain spells, anything else is a waste, unless you draw the majority of your deck into your hand as well just in the event the ramp spell is countered.

Regarding this card by itself, it's scary. Wrath of God is a rare that costs 2WW and yet this thing is that card + five 1/1 soldiers if you only pay 3 more (5WW). This should have been a mythic rare. It only takes a well placed Doubling Season or Parallel Lives prior to dropping this to make that at least 10 tokens and field advantage. Let's not forget there are seveval cards that boost tokens or just creatures in general (Caged Sun comes to mind).

Mind you it is a late game play kind of card, but you typically would find the need to board wipe mid to late game anyway, otherwise you focus on getting your Condemn or Oblivion Ring out early to stop the worst of the early drops, as you always hope for.

To me, White Sun's Zenith just looks sad in comparison to this card, despite the fact that WSZ will shuffle up your deck, is reusable (as long as it does not get countered or milled into your graveyard), and gives you 2/2 tokens vs the 1/1 tokens. Not that WSZ is overall bad, this card just makes it feel like one of the two needs to cost one W more or less. Soldiers have more power when you consider playing a Captain of the Watch, Catapult Master, Field Marshal, after a Martial Coup. I'd have suggested Leyline of the Meek, if it was not for the fact it helps the opponent(s) out as well, which is bad if it's token deck VS token deck. Soldiers are just better tokens than cats.

@Salient: Darksteel Plate your child and it is not an issue anymore. Also, in EDH CoA would go into your Commander Zone, so the ability to destroy the field never goes off... EVER, unless you chose to put CoA into the graveyard instead.

179235: Path to Exile.author: redhaiku
179235: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
Like a good cheap removal card, Path is a double edged sword of goodness. On one hand, you need to decide the appropriate time to kill that creature without giving them the jump in mana (you may, if they're colour or mana screwed, decide that NOT Pathing a creature will help you more). But once you do, that creature is gonezo! They're NOT unearthing (see ya, Shambling Mound!) nor are they persisting (you too, Kitchen Finks!).

Even better, much like Swords to Plowshares, you have the opportunity to use the spell on your own creature in order to move yourself ahead if you are stuck. Unlike with Plow, which can give you enough life to reach the next turn (and hopefully the win), Pathing your own creature can give you that important next mana OR prevent you from being colour screwed (something that is especially important during the Alara block!).

Finally, for us cheap people, it's an uncommon that isn't ridiculously easy to get... you have to work to find it, but still can get a full set for about twenty bucks.

With that, I give Path to Exile a 5/5 as a card that should be in EVERY deck playing white... making it a flexible tool that you should use carefully, like any very good magic card.

179235: Path to Exile.author: h4mx0r
179235: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
This is an amazingly good removal card, but it fixes your opponent's lands. Is it worth it? Probably, but just keep an eye out. I had one game at an FNM where my opponent was manascrewed for one color. I could have used Path to Exile to make the field a little easier for me deal with, but that may actually have been a bad move. Thankfully, I decided not to play Path, and managed to win because my opponent was unable to play half her hand.

Also, play it on your own creatures right before they're about to die to fetch a free land if you can't hit your opponent.

179235: Path to Exile.author: durdent
179235: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
Could have been better if the free basic land is put into the player's hand instead of directly into play. There's a high percentage that you might need to play this in the early turns to remove a threat (2nd turn staples like Bloodghast or Hellspark Elemental), and you certainly don't want to give your opponent that quick mana boost. At least your opponent will have 3 lands next turn instead of 4. The "delay" factor becomes critical.

Consider this disturbing but not implausible scenario: You use this card to exile your opponent's Bloodghast, but then the free comes-into-play land fishes out the other Bloodghast in his graveyard! God help you if he has more than one in his graveyard eagerly awaiting landfall. And with the popularity of vampire decks nowadays, this situation might happen more often than you'd expect.

All things considered, this is still a solid card. Swords to Plowshares is still better, though. 4/5

This card itself is under-costed and at instant speed with no real counter minus a counter-spell, bounce, or maybe Vines of Vastwood.

Soft counters won't work, this thing is too cheap in mana cost, if they have to pay an extra 1-2 of any color? They'll pay it to remove that creature they don't like. And Blue is getting pwned sadly ): No recent good non-land cards minus new Jace, Treasure Hunt, and Archive trap imo (and you can run archive trap in MONO white with this card O_O). Reprint Disrupt! Blue's answer to all the one drop's for each color. Path, Duress, Lightning Bolt, eer cant think of one for green lol. Maybe but nah, just let them decide..I just want to see old cards again XD.

Anyway 5/5 rating for the card, Instant at 1White mana creature exile for this cost? Crazy, not as good as Swords. But still awesome cause you can actually use this to force somebody to activate your archive trap, Or just exile their big creature without them gaining a bunch of life.

179235: Path to Exile.author: SleetFox
179235: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
This is exceedingly powerful. Not only is it an extremely effective mid- and late-game removal spell that can be played reflexively with only a single mana open, it also functions as early-game acceleration if you're feeling brash enough to take the card disadvantage. I'm thinking two lands on the first turn with Ornithopter. Very rarely is it the wisest way to use this, but the fact that even if such a situation never comes up, you still have the best single-creature removal spell since Swords to Plowshares makes that not really matter much. You can also play it early on a huge, cheap threat like Tarmogoyf, but it's almost never a good idea.

If you're a non-Spike in casual games, it can also be used as a mercy card on a player suffering from mana drought, and it doesn't even feel that much like charity since you're taking a creature.

179235: Path to Exile.author: Mike-C
179235: Path to Exile.text_parsed: So which is better, Swords to Plowshares or Path to Exile? This is an opinionated topic, so here's mine. If it were draft, Swords would get the edge, in that scenario, 9 times out of 10 you'll be using this only on your opp and i'll gladly give you 1-6 life over a free not to forget ADDITIONAL land. With that said however, I do believe that this card, when properly built around, CAN an often will be more dangerous.. This logic seems to be a trend in MTG these days (bringing back old powerhouses, changing the name and giving them an ability with a clause that only makes them better than their predecessor in the right scenario(s), a prime example of this would be Avacyn Restored's "Miracle" cards). Any whoo, putting this card in the right deck could give you added speed in the event you find yourself mana screwed but also be your source of removal with a tolorable drawback (I say tolorable because the majority of the time, if you're going to give your opp 1 additional land, chances are he/she already has enough to play his/her threats because obviously they already did and 1 additional land (to them) is most likely water under the bridge.. Note: NOTHING in Magic is Full-proof, not even the most feared Power-9. If that were the case, this beloved game would go down in a burning heap of stalemate. Too conclude: I personally like this card better for the versatility. Yes, I would rather give life points instead of land to my opp in exchange for 1 of his/her guys, but I myself would rather recieve a land when using it on myself and in the right deck, such as my U/W control in which I run 4 of's of this and Misthollow Griffin, it ROCKS. If you play a card like this ONLY for removal, pick yourself up a playset of S2P, but if it's versatility you're looking for, this is the one you want. Thanks for listening! :))

179245: Viashino Slaughtermaster.author: DarthParallax
179245: Viashino Slaughtermaster.text_parsed:
One of the few creatures where it's actually a kindness and a good thing that it's ability says "Activate only once each turn". Feasableness wise, I just don't see it being good to be activating this more than once a turn. If your deck is THAT Gold, it can do better things with Green and Black than to cast Red creatures. BUT, lets say you're a Red-based Jund deck running pretty much 4 Savage Lands and maybe only 5-6 other lands that produce colored non-Red mana? THEN this guy is a really cool option as an early drop to help you fight through the middle game and get to the end game where you slam down Hellkite Overlord.

It's NOT an ability I'd want to be tempted into trying to activate as a mana sink, because the hoops you have to go through for that aren't gonna end up worth it, but it most definitely IS worth it just like this, and maybe throw in some Rancor in your deck, some other this-and-thats, and make a nice Budget Jund build that's actually Jund-flavored. (Bloodbraid Elves need not apply)

179248: Matca Rioters.author: JaxsonBateman
179248: Matca Rioters.text_parsed:
While this card has a lot of potential (a 5/5 for 3 mana without some pumping ability is pretty nice), it has to deal with requiring one of each basic land to be on the field. Which is problematic given that one of the main sources of mana fixing is to use dual and tri lands.

Compare it with Woolly Thoctar - you lose 1 toughness and get a stricter casting cost, but don't need to ensure you have one of each basic land in play.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: nineyears
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
Master Transmuter is one of my favorite cards in the alara block. Her ability is so powerful... it can be use to protect your artifacts (including herself) from this like Path to Exile, Oblivion Ring, Bant Charm, etc., or you can bring a bomb into play for just one island. She basically very hard to get rid of once she comes into play and survives her sickness.

She is more of a quaterback in my esper deck and when she is in play is almost a definite win, and with the help of Sphinx Summoner I can go and get whatever creature I want for the right situation. Need to gain life in your Esper deck? Try Parasitic Strix and/or Filigree Angel bounce them back and foward at your opponent end of turn.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: DarkbladeWraith
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
Counterspell will only effect an opponent's SPELL (IE: a card that is coming into play). Master Transmuter, however, is using an ACTIVATED ABILITY (an effect caused by a permanant already in play) so Counterspell (or any card that targets a spell, like Countersquall for example) doesn't work.

Even better: Since Master Transmuter's ability requires Mana to work, it is considered a 'Mana Ability', which means that cards like Azorius Guildmage, Voidmage Husher, Voidslime, etc all the rest WON'T counter it either!

179252: Master Transmuter.author: mkniffen
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
I like some of the nonobvious things you can do with this

if you have an untapped master transmuter, and an opponent targets your say, darksteel colossus with path to exile, you can activate master transmuter and return the darksteel colossus to your hand and play him again. Since he is a completely new target, the opponent loses their path.

Also, you attack with that darksteel colossus and then during your second main phase you activate transmuter on darksteel and put him into play able to block. Essentially giving him vigilance.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Rainyday2012
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed: @DarkbladeWraith: Her ability isn't a mana ability. A mana ability produces mana, like Birds of Paradise, Black Lotus or Plains, not one that requires mana as a cost. (Though there are mana abilities that require mana, too.) Mana abilities don't use the stack and can't be targeted, Master Transmuter's ability can be targeted, responded to and countered. Usually it doesn't matter though, if your opponent lets you untap with this in play, it's most likely game.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: ArKive
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
other cards that work very nicely with Master Transmuter
Kaleidostone - return it to your hand to play a card from your hand, then play Kaleidostone again to keep your hand healthy.
Platinum Angel - I shall say no more.
Filigree Angel - Bouncing this card to your hand and back to the field once or more times per turn seems a little unfair on your opponent. Usually by the time this guy comes out you could expect to have about 7 artifacts on the field (Fieldmist Borderpost, Mistvein Borderpost, Obelisk of Esper, Kaleidostone, Master Transmuter, Etherium Sculptor, and Filigree Angel as its effect resolves after is has hit the field). That is a total life gain of 21, if you have only 1 Master Transmuter on the field.
Darksteel Colossus
Sharuum the Hegemon - Because it brings an artifact back from the graveyard, and it is not conditional to Sharuum being on the field (ie; when Sharuum leaves the field, the artifact brought back does not leave as well) Master Transmuter can Manage 1 of these guys once per turn. Also, I would like to note, if you have 2 Sharuums, you can create an infinite loop of Sharuums going to the graveyard and comeing back again, which can heavily benefit some card combos, having a power 5 creature enter the battlefield repeatedly. This infinite loop would be quite rude with anEssence Warden or Soul Warden in play
Sphinx Summoner - Managing one of these will give you the ability to pick the creature from your library which u need most at this point in time, and using Master Transmuter, play it for a blue
Inkwell Leviathan - only problem is, u cant then use Master Transmuter to bounce Inkwell to your hand, as it has shroud, so if u have no other targets to bounce, u have to bounce Master Transmuter
Tezzeret the Seeker - Tez can manage 2 Master Transmuters per turn, giving you incredible power. Sphinx summoner played for a blue gets you the creature u need, your second Master Transmuter plays it for another 1blue. Tez then untaps both of them, and you can do it again. If you're using your Master Transmuters to play a Sharuum, then you can use Transmuters ability, bouncing Sharuum to the field, retrieving (insert card name here) from your graveyard. then use your second Transmuter to do that again. then untap both Transmuters with Tez, and do it once more, keeping a single Transmuter untapped to counter your opponents artifact destruction.
Metallurgeon - A Master Transmuter will win the game for you if you can keep it on the field for at least 1 turn. It should really be called Magnetic Transmuter, due to the way your opponent stares at it and at their hand repeatedly after you play the thing. Metallurgeon helps keep it alive.

Master Transmuter is vulnerable to getting Path to Exiled as it hits the field, and correct me if I'm wrong, but i also believe effects like Disfigure cannot be regenerated from, since the card being regenerated still has -2/-2 this turn, as it has not actually left the field. I am not sure of this, so if anyone has more info, please advise me

179252: Master Transmuter.author: JaxsonBateman
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
I'd imagine the only reason this isn't a mythic rare is due to the weak body (1/2 for 4 mana isn't too flash). The ability is certainly a game winner if not quelled quickly. It's essentially part Elvish Piper, part Unsummon - thanks to which, you can constantly reactivate the many come-into-play abilities for effectively 1 island.

The last few games I've played have all ended up virtually the same: Master Transmuter and Sanctum Gargoyle out with a Scourglass in the graveyard. At the end of the opponent's turn transmute the Gargoyle into itself and withdraw the Scourglass from the graveyard. Use Scourglass as needed, then repeat the combo to get it out of the graveyard if you do.

Whilst I haven't come up against it myself, Pithing Needle would be a real combo breaker though. I usually play with one Dispellers Capsule for destroying important opposition artifacts (ie. Eldrazi or Platinum Angel), so I can only hope that it either isn't in the graveyard at the time, or I still have one of my graveyard searches in my hand or library. ^^ On the plus side, if Transmuter is untapped when Pithing Needle comes out and you DO have a Sanctum Gargoyle/Sharuum in play as well as a Dispellers Capsule in the graveyard, you can use a last ditch transmute (just as Pithing Needle goes on the stack) to get it out again.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: durdent
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
For those who think that being a 1/2 makes this card easy to get rid off despite its tremendous combo potential, read the Rulings on the Details tab of this page.

Holy crap, the rulings make this card invincible as long as it's untapped and you have one blue mana to spare. The only other time it's vulnerable is when it still has summoning sickness. Naturalize, Terminate, Path to Exile, etc. -- no problem. Simply bounce it back to your hand to avoid the effect, (paying a cost cannot be responded to; and if you choose to return MT to your hand, that is part of the cost) then put it back into play. If the opponent uses a battlefield-sweeping effect like Wrath of God or Nevinyrral's Disk, you can choose not to play this card when you bounce it back to your hand because the rules text in the card says, "You may put an artifact card from your hand into play." She can also block a huge attacker and leave unscathed. Sweet! And freakin' awesome art too! 5/5
179252: Master Transmuter.text_posted:
For those who think that being a 1/2 makes this card easy to get rid off despite its tremendous combo potential, read the Rulings on the Details tab of this page.  

Holy crap, the rulings make this card invincible as long as it's untapped and you have one blue mana to spare.  The only other time it's vulnerable is when it still has summoning sickness.  Naturalize, Terminate, Path to Exile, etc. -- no problem.  Simply bounce it back to your hand to avoid the effect, (paying a cost cannot be responded to; and if you choose to return MT to your hand, that is part of the cost) then put it back into play.  If the opponent uses a battlefield-sweeping effect like Wrath of God or Nevinyrral's Disk, you can choose not to play this card when you bounce it back to your hand because the rules text in the card says, "[b]You may[/b] put an artifact card from your hand into play."  She can also block a huge attacker and leave unscathed.  Sweet!  And freakin' awesome art too!  5/5

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Pugnator
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
lol, she really looks like a friend of mine.
although it has some combo potential a tinker would be better for various reasons:

1- this is a creature, and it probably won't survive one turn with all the removal and affinity hate in extended, which is the best format for artifact decks imo (i don't like legacy).

2- it has a converted mana cost of 4, meaning you'll probably be dead or pretty close to dead when you play it an trigger it's ability (personal experience).

3- it will just get a path once you trigger it, unless you return it to you hand instead of picking another artifact, in which case they'll just break the artifact you just put into play.

4- ancient grudge and kataki in every sideboard i see... :(

5- there was actually a deck playing with this, but it never went very far and i don't think it won any major tounaments.

although it's pretty good for amateur decks. you should check the power nine if you want to see broken, they'll let you win at the 1st turn without drawback.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Tiplady
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
Rather than Ornithopter/Bonesaw/ect for 0, I prefer Sigil of Distinction, the X mana cost can be played for 0 to sit in wait of her ability, and in times of need, or lategame when you don't need the massive manapool, you can pump Sigil into a comeback card, at very worst you play it for 2 and give a creature +1/+1 so bonesaw beats it there, but in a transmuter deck that scenario is rare, and most likely wont have made the difference. Also, Sigil's biggest problem is the fact that it will eventually run out of counters if re-equipped multiple times, so bouncing with Master can help Sigil just as much as it helps Master by being fodder for more devistating artifacts.

Best choice for a bounce is an artifact you control being targeted with destruction or removal, but it seems like everyone agrees it's a good idea to run a few low/free casting cost artifacts to get the ball rolling, and Sigil is my favorite.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Gaussgoat

Amazing card, como-tastic. I have to confess, I don't think it is "entirely" broken since she costs 4CC to get into the battlefield, and won't be able to toggle her ability untill after that.

That having been said, awesome power-house of a card capable of bringing in a winning threat for virtually no cost. Anything that allows you to turn Library of Leng into a Darksteel Forge has to be considered a major threat.

She is also excellent for protecting your creatures from targeted spells AND triggering combos on arrival/departure effects like Glaze Fiend for example.

5/5

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Azazyel
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
Such an astoundingly beautiful card. Incredible art, incredible frame, incredible flavor, incredible ability. A million times better than Elvish Piper, since for her color she's more easy to fetch, she can place any artifact down on the field (not just creatures), the bounce is more of an advantage than a drawback (easily circumvented with Ornithopter, Mishra's Bauble, etc. or easily abused with Filigree Angel, Sharuum, etc.), and a Blue artifact deck is going to have a much, much easier time protecting her than a Green beatdown deck is going to have protecting the Piper. (Just off the top of my head, besides counterspells - Welding Jar.)

Also, Thousand Year Elixir, Etherium Sculptor, Vedalken Engineer. Screw you, summoning sickness and 4cmc.

179252: Master Transmuter.author: Zulp
179252: Master Transmuter.text_parsed: I use her in so many different ways in my artifact deck. Sure, the most obvious application is cheating my expensive artifacts, like the Darksteels Colossus and Forge into play, but I also use her to allow my artifacts to dodge targeted destruction and repeat beneficial CIP effects. What's especially fun (and no one really sees it coming in the current metagame) is to have more than one on the field and repeatedly bounce a Heap Doll or similar with Reaper King in play. Her ability becomes ": Destroy target permanent."

179434: Noble Hierarch.author: Cheezinator
179434: Noble Hierarch.text_parsed: For years, one could argue using Llanowar Elves over Birds of Paradise because having 1 power was a valuable thing. Noble Hierarch has ended that debate. The only thing Birds still have going for them is that they can fly in carrying a sword. The role of Llanowar Elves has been reduced to tribal decks :(

179434: Noble Hierarch.author: j_mindfingerpainter
179434: Noble Hierarch.text_parsed:
@ TheWrathofShane: Actually prices are determined by five things:

How awesome the card is
How many people think the card is awesome
The rarity of the card
What formats the card is legal in
How long the card has been out

Even if the card is legal in all formats, is brand new, is rare (or even mythic), and is awesome, it doesn't necessarily make it expensive if no one else likes the card. Torpor Orb for example. It did a fair amount of stuff in Standard sideboards and TONS in Modern sideboards. But because not many people bought playsets, it was ~1.95 when it was legal in Standard.
179434: Noble Hierarch.text_posted:

179434: Noble Hierarch.author: Mistralis
179434: Noble Hierarch.text_parsed:
@FourEx If you can't appreciate ramp, then sorry, there's nothing I can do for you there. It's like learning not to target your opponent with Sign in Blood.

@Laguz You can't compare those cards; they fulfill completely different purposes. Noble Hierarch is for fixing, ramp, and providing extra damage. Mother of Runes is for saving creatures or blocking single ones. Sometimes she will be used to make creatures unblockable, but that usually doesn't happen, and it's more likely for your opponent to have more than one creature color than more than one Mother of Runes. They have almost no overlap besides the fact that they're both 1-mana humans with a tap ability.

179434: Noble Hierarch.author: jonrds

@TheWrathofShane

I totally agree with you. Getting a mana base for Simic is annoyingly expensive. When birds are the only 1 drop ramp you can use, thats $10 out the door right there. Add in 4 Hinterland Harbor and thats another $10. It adds up quickly when you are looking to spend around $50 on a deck.

I'm fine with Spike's having their top-tier, $50 cards, I just wish there were some slightly more specialized cards for budget players that wouldn't set them behind in tempo. We don't need flying and any color of mana or exalted or any of those fancy things, we just want to be able to reliably drop a color intensive 3 drop turn 2.

179437: Conflux.author: ICEFANG13
179437: Conflux.text_parsed:
I agree that this card sucks, the rare times I get to cast it in my mono green deck, I only can tutor for one card!

/heavy sarcasm

If you don't get 5 targets outta this deal (perhaps 4) then its not really worth it, just because its so expensive, even with those 3/2/1 cards, you can't do much with them.

However, in a 5 colored deck (which I'm sure you have played it in) then it tutors 'any' 5 cards for 8 mana? That is extremely cost efficient.

If there was no color restriction, it would easily be an extremely good card, if you are saying this card really sucks, I would think your deck doesn't handle this card very well. Either you want it looking for 5 cards of a combo in your deck, or you can look for some WUBRG creatures. If its a dedicated 5 color deck, with mostly WUBRG and Domain effects, you can do a lot of damage with what you want, in a good WUBRG deck, that is designed to use this, its easy Mythic Rare

I agree with a little too expensive though, 7 wouldn't be crazy OP

179437: Conflux.author: Ferlord
179437: Conflux.text_parsed:
A perfect card for any 5-coloured Sliver EDH deck (I mean, why wouldn't you play a Sliver as your general anyway?).

Pick out 5 different slivers and, as long as they can get haste, you can win in one go. Choosing Bonescythe Sliver, Shifting Sliver, Sliver Legion, Heart Sliver, and Megantic Sliver and playing them all at the same time gets the 5 slivers and nets you exactly 100 damage which can hardly be blocked. Coincidence? I think not.

Mind you, it'll cost you ...

(All of them get +3/+3 (megantic) and +4/+4 (legion), adding +7/+7 times 5 for the slivers, their base power equals 15. 7x5=35, 35+15=50, and double strike makes that 100)

also i love that fact that you don't have to exile the card after playing it again

179438: Charnelhoard Wurm.author: blurrymadness
179438: Charnelhoard Wurm.text_parsed:
This guy IS a game winner.
-Soul's Fire combo, as mentioned
-Cruel Ultimatum every turn with this guy

The other thing is as a side note, people need to stop caring about mana costs once they're above 6ish. They stop being "playable" at 5ish if you're not using:
-a ramp
-an alternate cost
-blah

I mean, you CAN play him for 7, but you'll be doing it turn 5ish. Turn six you swing, cast a cruel ultimatum. If they don't give up. Do it again. Same mana cost; same colors. Seems like a fine idea.

In eternal formats I'd imagine you'd piper him into play, or tooth and nail, or any number of other "free creature" cards. If it's 7 mana, the idea is probably not to cast him but to cheat him in. if you do that, he's just as lethal as Darksteel or similar.

179438: Charnelhoard Wurm.author: SocialExperiment
179438: Charnelhoard Wurm.text_parsed:
I love this guy. I have a fairly straightforward beatdown deck (same colours as the Wurm here) and I use this guy to get some of my more useful cards back. One of my main strategies is to play Prized Unicorn, give him Gorgon's Flail (+1/+1 and deathtouch), and then attack (and maybe power him up with Giant Growth). Wipe out the opposing creatures, attack with Charnelhoard Wurm, get Prized Unicorn back, and repeat. He's slightly expensive, but I don't see why seven mana has to be a gamewinner so that doesn't bother me in the least. His effect makes up for it, I think.

EDIT: You ever take a look at opinions you held years ago, and wonder what you were thinking? Finding this comment has been one of those moments for me.

179440: Quenchable Fire.author: JaxsonBateman
179440: Quenchable Fire.text_parsed:
Not the worst burn spell ever - if you're smart about it, it's always going to be 6 damage (against a blue deck just cast it when they've tapped out; they have to pay the mana *before* their upkeep, and the first time they can do so in a turn is the upkeep - so obviously too late).

While you get more efficiency at the lower end of the spectrum with burn spells (like Lightning Bolt and Lava Spike dealing 3 damage for 1 mana, when you're getting up to values of 6 damage in a single card not many are this efficient.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: ZursApprentice
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed: I very strongly disagree with people that rate this card poorly.  Granted there are very few decks that can play him, but in those that can he is brilliant.  I play a 5 color planeswalker deck that gets up to over ten mana every game and can survive for that long EVERY game.  (It is very different than AJ Sachers  build)  With Wraths, Condemns, Volcanic Fallouts, Austere Commands, planewalkers (esp. Garruk), etc. it is very easy to get up the mana.  Some people say it is worse than Cruel Ultimatum and that is probably true in the typical 5 color control decks but in my planeswalker deck this is clearly better.  In my deck each players life totals are largely irrelevant because I rarely go below 10 life and have ajani goldmane to usually keep above 20 and I usually do not win by chipping away my opponents life total.  The deck also runs 0 creatures main and 0 creatures side, so the pulling the creature from your gy never happens.  Forcing the opponent to sac one creature is generally insignificant.  So in that deck Cruel Ultimatuum basically just allows me to draw 3 and my opponent to discard 3, which is good enough to run 1 of but not earth shattering and certainly does not win me the game outright.  Nicol Bolas on the other hand wins the game 90% of the time he hits.  I usually just target a land with his plus ability, he gets up to his ultimate the 3rd turn he hits, which forces the opponent to sac most of his lands, discards whatever they have in their hand, and they lose 7 life.  If they ever play another land it just gets destroyed immediately and the ultimate goes off again a couple of turns later.  Or if they have creatures you need to take care of you can take whatever of those you need and recruit them to your side.  Plus, it is essential in the mirror to pick off their other planewalkers.  In brief, it wins the game.  Period.  I can always hit the mana and its better than milling with jace or putting creatures into play from the graveyard with Liliana thats for sure!

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Elven_planeswalker
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
I still will never get what all the rage is on bolas, ive played against him many times. My simple solution:
1. Faiths fetters bolas
2. clear out your opponents defenses with your big creatures, you've had time to play them becasue of bolas's high cost
3. kill bolas with your creatures, you shouldnt have taken too much damage from him at this point
4. if you have a planeswalker, play it (if you dont have one skip this step)
5. move on to your opponent for the win
My recomendation is use the divine deck (in duel decks "divine vs. demonic") and add in ajani goldmane and/or elspeth (both planeswalkers) if you have them. You might want to take out one charging paladin and then, if your adding a second card, angelic protector. akroma hurts bad, good for killing bolas. do this and bolas wont provide you with any trouble. the only thing is your way, is getting faith's fetters or the divine deck :P.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Trev1369
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed: I just got him in a pack the other day and I use him, but only because I can. I don't think anyone can deny the fact that this card has to be one of the most powerful plainswalkers, but there are certain rules everyone must know before even thinking of putting one of them in their deck. In my opinion, one major factor you have to remeber is "Don't rely on the plainswalker only to win your duels". If you focus on that only, the chances of winning may be much slimmer. You always have to have a back up strategy just incase you don't happen to draw the card throughout the duel. Onc you do, and you have a killer strategy, chances are you'll probably win. Trust me I have Nicol Bolas and if I draw him and play him I 98% of the time win the duel. This statement is from my own personal experiences. !!! :) !!!

You always have to have a back up strategy just incase you don't happen to draw the card throughout the duel. Onc you do, and you have a killer strategy, chances are you'll probably win. Trust me I have Nicol Bolas and if I draw him and play him I 98% of the time win the duel. This statement is from my own personal experiences. !!! :) !!!

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: The_Somnambulist
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
I pull off that mana cost all the time in my deck, where I have stuff like Blood Tyrant and Thraximundar.

I just wish I didn't have such a hard time getting this card :P

edit: I just got the card online :-)

Come to think of it, Bolas is a bit better than Ajani Vengeant in that with his +3 ability, you can kill the opponent's lands one by one, then, if and when you unleash the ultimate, they will be somewhat hard pressed to decide which 7 permanents they will sacrifice, b/c no matter if they sacrifice more creatures and/or other permanents than land permanents, they will already be low on lands due to your bit of destruction you did to their mana pool. then you just keep killing their lands and repeat, it's quite crippling to any deck constructed with cards from the Alara block in general.

The only diff btw Bolas and Ajani Vengeant as far as land destruction is that pulling of Ajani's ultimate will wipe out the opponent's mana pool entirely in one turn, vs. Bolas would be one per turn, however land destruction is happening as Bolas grows in power, then in the longer run, they have an even harder time coming back b/c their choice of permanents to sacrifice during the ultimate effect is way too difficult, and as their mana pool shrinks from destruction, the chances of Bolas being tripped up by some spell decreases, whereas Ajani can be more at risk.

*edit 2* I have 2 Maelstrom Archangels now and they sometimes win me the game very fast b/c I'll either have followed it up with Progenitus, or a planeswalker like said card here. Then again, Mindwrack Liege also does the job for all your expensive red and blue creatures besides Progenitus.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Vorthosian
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
This is an excellent, underrated card for Spikes. It's also obviously good for Timmies and Vorthoses. Sorry Johnny.

Any control deck that runs Grixis colors should run at least one copy of this guy. He's an excellent finisher, especially against the midrange decks that are dominating the meta. If you drop this guy, you will win unless your opponent manages to find an answer very quickly.

The mana is actually a little bit better than Cruel Ultimatum in a lot of decks, so I don't know why people complain about that so much. You're certainly getting enough bang for your buck.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: DonRoyale
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Despite being more of a casual card than a competitive one, let's look at what he does competitively.

-He answers Baneslayer Angel. How? By making your opponent answer it. This is also true for any non-shroud creature in general; he answers any creature threat the best way possible; by shifting the pressure right to your opponent. This often turns the tide of the entire game. Have you ever taken a Baneslayer? Even if it just got hit by Path to Exile, that's in theory a 3-card tempo swing; your opponent loses their Baneslayer and their removal spell, and you get a land! And Nicol Bolas is still alive (though in Lightning Bolt range, sadly)
-He's great in a match against any Control deck, specifically Cruel Control, as it keeps the lands in check so the opponent can't cast Cruel for the rest of the game, provided the opponent doesn't have Crumbling Necropolis with the rest of the mana that can cast it.
-He also wrecks Jund's frail manabase by attacking it. Sadly, this is the only thing he offers against Jund before Maelstrom Pulse just makes it go kasplat.
-He kills other Planeswalkers. Dead.
-His ultimate. Enough said.

I love him to pieces. He's my absolute favorite Planeswalker ever. :D

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Ever been Nicol Bolased turn 2? Its great fun
Turn 1
Forest, Birds of Paradise
Turn 2
Lotus Cobra, Fetchland, Sac Fetchland, Lotus Cobra, Path to Exile the birds, Explore, Fetchland, Sac Fetchland, Explore, Fetchland, Sac Fetchland. NICOL BOLAS
That right there is how you can make someone stop playing Magic for ever, the only problem i have found is that the second turn Bolas requires exactly 11 cards, so you have to go second, and you have to draw fetchlands off of your Explores.
can anyone name a card that removes Nicol Bolas for 2 mana? the only 1 i can think of is Vampire Hexmage, so as long as your not versing vampires or mbc then the game is in the bag.

ps: the chance of having the exact 7 spells and drawing 3 fetchlands and a forest or 4 fetchlands is about 1 in 20, so good luck :)

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Elder_Kraken
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Great control, great defense, gives you instant options. Cool style. I'm using him in a Superfriends-style multi-player Sopranos deck with him as the mob boss, the 1st Chandra, Liliana, Tezzeret and Sorin. With mana acceleration and/or Tezzeret with artifact lands to pull out of the deck or untap lands, he'll come out quickly enough to be useful after a Damnation clears the air and give top-cover for the other Planeswalkers to do their thing. Just a brutal card, so looking forward to using him in conjunction with Sorin and Co.

I understand the hexmage weakness, but with some prudent planning, you should be able to keep him in play (hexmage is one of the few things that can kill him, so worth planning for.) Just a thought.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: DarthParallax
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
@Axelle- he's got the same loyalty as Vess, for the same reason- you can buy his loyalty. he's not just a mindless savage evil that tries to destroy everybody. He's much more devious than that. He's the ultimate Chessmaster- he's everybody's ally, and he cackles with glee as his pawns kill each other off on his orders, for his personal amusement. There's not much left interesting for him to do, being All Powerful. Further more, Loyalty is a combination of alignment and toughness- 5 is the minimum I would accept. He shrugs off Bolts, and even a Lava Axe isn't particularly disturbing if you remembered to Strip Mine them when he comes out.


Compare this guy's mana-cost to power ratio with Progenitus' or Emrakul's. Emrakul may actually be stronger than Bolas, but only at TWICE the mana! Progenitus dies very badly to both. Nothing has 'protection from sacrifice'!

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: CrowJonSnow
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
definitely a great card, but i don't think he's the best planeswalker;
for one, i find his mana cost to be a big bump to get over. the different colors, one of them double, and 4 of any other. a bit hard to hard cast, and i can't think of anything off the top of my head that can get around that.

his first ability is insane in the sense that is can kill any other planeswalker, and any supporting cards your opponent has. if, however, your opponent has a ton of creatures out, nicol can't do a whole lot.
his second is good, but you probably won't use it as much as the first and last. still good though.

his third is, more often than not, a game changer, but not all the time. the seven damage isn't a huge deal, since he seems to fit a UB deck more, and those aren't big on burn.
the seven permanents is a big deal and can easily clear your field. even if you only sac seven lands, you're now down by a huge land amount. seven discard is also great, but if you have a great field, it's not a huge deal.

he is a great planeswalker, but i think his mana cost is a bit crazy. however, he fits his colors very well;
his first ability is black, his second is blue, and his third is a combo of all three (UBR).

4/5

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Kura-san
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed: In a Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker deck, you'd want a playset of Nightscape Familiars. Why? Because each has the ability to make blue and red spells 1 colorless mana less to play, but it doesn't stack on UR cards. However, the ability stacks with multiple Nightscape Familiars. So, with one out, Bolas' CMC becomes 7. Another one and it's 6. With a bit of luck, a rite of replication, or other copy creators, Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker could have a CMC of 4.

179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Zoah
179441: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
I remember the first time I saw someone play this card. He played the plainswalker, stole my Ertie, wizard adept and ended his turn. I took my turn, Confiscateed Nico, and used him to steal my Ertie back. I ended the game shortly there after. (Me stealing the most expensive planswalker in the game sent me on a power trip of a week)

Ironically, I later got the card from him, so I now own it. (Thought he didn't need it after he got Jace, the Mind Sculptor, though I still had to trade half a deck for it).

I will admit, he is harder to summon than I thought. Although, I did underestimate his ultimate; the first time I got him out I used it. This left my opponent with an empty hand, two lands left on the field, and Zero life. (Another week long power trip)

So at any rate, His plus ability is nice, at worst, it disarms your opponent by killing his lands. At best, he just ate your opponent's with twelve loyalty counters (It's only a matter of time). That, and he gets plus three loyalty, more than his minus ability costs.

Another fun thing about him is that he has flexibility. With Espeth or the Elf lady you have one direction: the ultimate. With this guy on the other hand... Yes, you can shoot for the ultimate, but it's also quite satisfying to just sit there and have him eat all of your opponent's lands while snagging a creature every other turn.
